description: From Middle English sovereyn, from Old French soverain (whence also modern French souverain), from Vulgar Latin *superānus (compare Italian sovrano, Spanish soberano) from Latin super (“above”). Spelling influenced by folk-etymology association with reign. Doublet of soprano, from the same Latin root via Italian. See also suzerain, foreign.

adjectives.description: sovereign (comparative more sovereign, superlative most sovereign)

examples: Her voice was her sovereign talent.

entries.meaning: (now rare, pharmacology) Extremely potent or effective (of a medicine, remedy etc.).

examples: Gentlemen, may I introduce Her Royal Highness, the Sovereign and Most Imperial Majesty, Empress Elizabeth of Vicron.
We acknowledge him [God] our sovereign good.

entries.meaning: A monarch; the ruler of a country.
examples: No question is to be made but that the bed of the Missisippi[sic] belongs to the sovereign, that is, to the nation.

definitionGroups.group: One who is not a subject to a ruler or nation.

entries.meaning: A gold coin of the United Kingdom, with a nominal value of one pound sterling but in practice used as a bullion coin.
A former Australian gold coin, minted from 1855–1931, of one pound value.
A very large champagne bottle with the capacity of about 25 liters, equivalent to 33+1⁄3 standard bottles.
Any butterfly of the tribe Nymphalini, or genus Basilarchia, as the ursula and the viceroy.
(UK, slang) A large, garish ring; a sovereign ring.
examples: No, someone who wears loads of sovereigns as well loads of gold and has uh a curly perm and peroxide blonde hair, orange, orange sunbed skin and a fringe like this blow-dried to death, that’s a ‘scally’.

verbs.description: sovereign (third-person singular simple present sovereigns, present participle sovereigning, simple past and past participle sovereigned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To rule over as a sovereign.
